As discussed in the introduction, a 401 Unauthorized Error indicates that the client (the web browser, in most cases) has requested a restricted resource (such as a web page) from the server, but the client has failed to provide valid authentication credentials.

comments.content: "The Cisco DNA Center platform supports Representational State Transfer (REST) APIs at the northbound layer for programmability. " Anything can be a layer in networking lol.
Really ? YAML output is also a layer ?

discussion.content: APIs are not layer. broken question. another to remember.
The given answer is correct

Intent API (Northbound)
The Intent API is a Northbound REST API that exposes specific capabilities of the Cisco DNA Center platform.
The Intent API provides policy-based abstraction of business intent, allowing focus on an outcome rather than struggling with individual mechanisms steps.
The RESTful Cisco DNA Center Intent API uses HTTPS verbs (GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE) with JSON structures to discover and control the network. For more information, see Intent API.

Answer is B

questions.question_text: At which layer does Cisco DNA Center support REST controls?

choices.D: YAML output from responses to API calls

comments.content: b-crypt to secure a REST API!

discussion.content:
https://restfulapi.net/security-essentials/
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct based on Chat GPT knowledge

Passwords must always be hashed to protect the system (or minimize the damage) even if it is compromised in some hacking attempts. There are many such hashing algorithms that can prove really effective for password security e.g. PBKDF2, bcrypt, and scrypt algorithms. (D)

comments.content:
D
One of the best practices to secure REST APIs is using password hash. Passwords must
always be hashed to protect the system (or minimize the damage) even if it is compromised in some hacking attempts. There are many such hashing algorithms which can prove really

effective for password security e.g. PBKDF2, bcrypt and scrypt algorithms.

Other ways to secure REST APIs are: Always use HTTPS, Never expose information on URLs
Usernames, passwords, session tokens, and API keys should not appear in the URL

discussion.content:
Answer is A.
MD5 & SHA-1 are legacy. PBKDF2 & SCrypt are considered uncrackable, but used by Cisco for local password encryption, and not REST functions.
